t: The*p burden against Damascus. “Behold,*pn Damascus will cease from being*i a city, And*ld it will be a ruinous heap.
The*ld cities of Aroer are*i forsaken; They*ld will be for flocks Which*ld lie down, and no one will make them*i afraid.
The*ld fortress also will cease from Ephraim, The*ld kingdom from Damascus, And*ld the remnant of Syria; They*ld will be as the glory of the children of Israel,” Says*ld the Lord*s of hosts.
“In*ln that day it shall come to pass That*ild the glory of Jacob will wane, And*ld the fatness of his flesh grow lean.
It*ld shall be as when the harvester gathers the grain, And*ld reaps the heads with his arm; It*ld shall be as he who gathers heads of grain In*ld the Valley of Rephaim.

Yet*ld gleaning grapes will be left in it, Like*ld the shaking of an olive tree, Two*ld or*i three olives at the top of the uppermost bough, Four*ld or*i five in its most fruitful branches,” Says*ld the Lord*s God of Israel.
In*ln that day a man will look to his Maker, And*ld his eyes will have respect for the Holy One of Israel.
He*ld will not look to the altars, The*ld work of his hands; He*ld will not respect what his fingers have made, Nor*ld the wooden images nor the incense altars.
In*ln that day his strong cities will be as a forsaken bough And*ld an uppermost branch, Which*ld they left because of the children of Israel; And*ld there will be desolation.
Because*ld you have forgotten the God of your salvation, And*ld have not been mindful of the Rock of your stronghold, Therefore*ld you will plant pleasant plants And*ld set out foreign seedlings;
In*ld the day you will make your plant to grow, And*ld in the morning you will make your seed to flourish; But*ild the harvest will*i be*i a heap of ruins In*ld the day of grief and desperate sorrow.
Woe*ln to the multitude of many people Who*ild make a noise like the roar of the seas, And*ld to the rushing of nations That*ild make a rushing like the rushing of mighty waters!

The*ld nations will rush like the rushing of many waters; But*ld God*i will rebuke them and they will flee far away, And*ld be chased like the chaff of the mountains before the wind, Like*ld a rolling thing before the whirlwind.
Then*ld behold, at eventide, trouble! And*ild before the morning, he is*i no more. This*ld is*i the portion of those who plunder us, And*ld the lot of those who rob us.
